module.name: Intuition
module.short: Screen and Window handling routines of intuition.library

element.name: PIntuiText
element.short: IntuiText is a series of strings.
element.descr: IntuiText is a series of strings that start with a screen location (always relative to the upper-left corner of something) and then the text of the string. The text is null-terminated.

element.name: PBorder
element.short: Pointer to Border Drawing structure
element.descr: Data type Border, used for drawing a series of lines which is intended for use as a border drawing, but which may, in fact, be used to render any arbitrary vector shape. The routine DrawBorder sets up the RastPort with the appropriate variables, then does a Move to the first coordinate, then does Draws to the subsequent coordinates. After all the Draws are done, if NextBorder is non-zero we call DrawBorder recursively

element.name: TBorder
element.short: Pointer drawing structure
element.descr: Data type Border, used for drawing a series of lines which is intended for use as a border drawing, but which may, in fact, be used to render any arbitrary vector shape. The routine DrawBorder sets up the RastPort with the appropriate variables, then does a Move to the first coordinate, then does Draws to the subsequent coordinates. After all the Draws are done, if NextBorder is non-zero we call DrawBorder recursively

element.name: TPropInfo
element.short: Proportional Gadget

descr.p: You initialize the Pot variables before the Gadget is added to the system. Then you can look here for the current settings any time, even while User is playing with this Gadget. To adjust these after the Gadget is added to the System, use ModifyProp() The Pots are the actual proportional settings, where a value of zero means zero and a value of means that the Gadget is set to its maximum setting.

The 16-bit FixedPoint Body variables describe what percentage of the entire body of stuff referred to by this Gadget is actually shown at one time. This is used with the routines, to adjust the size of the according to how much of the data can be seen. This is also used to decide how far to advance the Pots when User hits the Container of the Gadget. For instance, if you were controlling the display of a 5-line Window of text with this Gadget, and there was a total of 15 lines that could be displayed, you would set the VertBody value to ( / (TotalLines / DisplayLines)) = / 3. Therefore, the would fill 1/3 of the container, and if User hits the Cotainer outside of the knob, the pot would advance 1/3 (plus or minus) If there's no body to show, or the total amount of displayable info is less than the display area, set the Body variables to the max. To adjust these after the Gadget is added to the System, use ModifyProp()

element.name: TImage
element.short: This is a brief image structure for very simple transfers of image data to a RastPort

descr.p: The TImage.PlanePick and PlaneOnOff variables work much the same way as the equivalent GELS Bob variables. It's a space-saving mechanism for image data. Rather than defining the image data for every plane of the RastPort, you need define data only for the planes that are not entirely zero or one. As you define your Imagery, you will often find that most of the planes ARE just as color selectors. For instance, if you're designing a two-color Gadget to use colors two and three, and the Gadget will reside in a five-plane display, bit plane zero of your imagery would be all ones, bit plane one would have data that describes the imagery, and bit planes two through four would be all zeroes. Using these flags allows you to avoid wasting all that memory in this way: first, you specify which planes you want your data to appear in using the PlanePick variable. For each bit set in the variable, the next "plane" of your image data is blitted to the display. For each bit clear in this variable, the corresponding bit in PlaneOnOff is examined. If that bit is clear, a "plane" of zeroes will be used. If the bit is set, ones will go out instead. So, for our example:
Gadget.PlanePick = $02;
Gadget.PlaneOnOff = $01;

Note that this also allows for generic Gadgets, like the System Gadgets, which will work in any number of bit planes. Note also that if you want an Image that is only a filled rectangle, you can get this by setting PlanePick to zero (pick no planes of data) and set PlaneOnOff to describe the pen color of the rectangle.

element.name: IDCMP_SIZEVERIFY
element.short: IDCMP class: resize must be verified by application
element.descr: Set this flag if the program must complete some operation before the user sizes the window. When the user sizes the window, Intuition sends an IDCMP_SIZEVERIFY message to the application and then waits until the program replies before allowing the user to size the window. See the "Verification Functions" section below for some things to consider when using this flag.

element.name: IDCMP_NEWSIZE
element.short: IDCMP class: User resized the Window
element.descr: Intuition sends this message after the user has resized the window. After receiving this, the program can examine the size variables in the window structure to discover the new size of the window. The message is sent, even if the size of the window did not actually change.

element.name: IDCMP_REFRESHWINDOW
element.short: IDCMP class: Window needs refreshing

descr.p: This message is sent whenever the window needs refreshing. This flag makes sense only with windows that have a refresh type of or .

As a minimum, the application must call BeginRefresh() and EndRefresh() for the window after receiving an IDCMP_REFRESHWINDOW event. Create the window with the attribute if you do not want to manage these events.

Most of the graphics library calls used for display output are compatible with Intuition, with the exception of ScrollRaster(). Intuition will not send an IDCMP_REFRESHWINDOW event when damage is caused to a window by ScrollRaster(). This may happen in a simple refresh window which is partially obscured by another window--the region that scrolls out from behind the front window will be damaged, but the window will receive no notification. Check the bit in the Layer structure Flags field to see if damage did happen as a result of ScrollRaster().

element.name: IDCMP_MOUSEBUTTONS
element.short: IDCMP class: Contains reports about mouse button up and down events.

descr.p: Contains reports about mouse button up and down events. The events will be sent to the application only if they are not used internally by Intuition.

The Code field contains information on the specific mouse button event this message represents. The Code field will be equal to , , , , or , depending on the button pressed or released. In general, the select button is the left mouse button, the menu button is the right mouse button and the middle button is an optional third button usually located between the select and menu buttons.

Often, a mouse button event has extra meaning to Intuition, and the application may hear about it through a more specific message, for example a gadget or menu event. Other times, no event is generated at all, such as when the user depth-arranges a screen by clicking on the screen depth gadget. Note that menu button events are normally consumed by Intuition for menu handling. If an application wishes to hear IDCMP_MOUSEBUTTONS events for the menu button, it must set the > attribute for its window.

element.name: IDCMP_MOUSEMOVE
element.short: IDCMP class: Reports about mouse movements

descr.p: Reports about mouse movements, sent in the form of x and y coordinates relative to the upper left corner of the window. One message will be sent to the application for each "tick" of the mouse.

The application can opt to receive IDCMP_MOUSEMOVE events only while certain gadgets are active, or during normal window operation. These events are sent whenever a gadget with gadget is active, or for any window that has the attribute set. This window attribute can be set or cleared by the application at will.

Requesting IDCMP_MOUSEMOVE messages can create a very large volume of messages arriving at the window's IDCMP. Do not request these messages unless the program is prepared to keep up with them. Intuition limits the number of mouse move events that pile up at your IDCMP.

All IDCMP messages contain a mouse x and y position that can be absolute values or delta values. See . If the application requires a less frequent reporting of the mouse position, consider using . While IDCMP_MOUSEMOVE events are generated by changes in the mouse's position, IntuiMessages are based on a timer. Since they contain mouse coordinates, they effectively sample the mouse position. These message come often enough for many applications, but not so frequently as to swamp the application.

The program will not be sent IDCMP_MOUSEMOVE messages while Intuition has the layers of the screen locked (during menu operations and window sizing/dragging). This avoids problems of messages accumulating while the program is blocked, waiting to render into a locked layer.

element.name: IDCMP_GADGETDOWN
element.short: IDCMP class: user selects a gadget
element.descr: IDCMP_GADGETDOWN messages are sent when the user selects a gadget that was created with the GACT_IMMEDIATE flag set. The IAddress field will contain a pointer to the selected gadget.

element.name: IDCMP_GADGETUP
element.short: IDCMP class: user selects a gadget
element.descr: IDCMP_GADGETUP messages are sent when the user selects a gadget that was created with the flag set. The IAddress field will contain a pointer to the selected gadget.

element.name: IDCMP_REQSET
element.short: IDCMP class: Recive message when a requester opens
element.descr: With this flag set, the program will receive a message whenever a requester opens in its window. The application will receive one IDCMP_REQSET event for each requester opened in the window.

element.name: IDCMP_MENUPICK
element.short: IDCMP class: User opened the menu
element.descr: This flag indicates that the user has pressed the menu button. If a menu item was selected, the menu number of the menu item can be found in the Code field. If no item was selected, the Code field will be equal to .

element.name: IDCMP_CLOSEWINDOW
element.short: IDCMP class: User pressed close button of window
element.descr: IDCMP_CLOSEWINDOW messages are sent when the user selects the window's close gadget. Intuition does not close the window when the close gadget is selected. Rather, an IDCMP_CLOSEWINDOW message is sent to the window's IDCMP. It is up to the application to clean up and close the window itself. If closing a window means losing some data (perhaps the spreadsheet the user was working on), it would be appropriate for the application to first confirm that the user really meant to close the window.

element.name: IDCMP_RAWKEY
element.short: IDCMP class: Raw keycodes from keyboard

descr.p: IDCMP_RAWKEY messages give the raw keycodes from the keyboard. The numeric value of the keycode is sent in the Code field. Separate codes are returned for key down and key up. Qualifier codes, such as Shift or Alt and whether this key is a repeat, may be found in the Qualifier field of the message.

In general, the application should not assume any correspondence between the keycode and the key value. Character positions on the keyboard change from country to country, and the application should respect the keymap set by the user.

Programs using IDCMP_RAWKEY messages should perform their own key mapping by calling the console.device function RawKeyConvert(), or the keymap.library function MapRawKey(). (The latter is a bit more convenient). The Autodoc for the MapRawKey() function shows how you can process so-called dead keys. A dead key is a key combination that has no immediate effect, but instead modifies a subsequent keystroke. For example, on the default keymap, Alt-F is a dead key for the acute accent mark. The sequence of Alt-F followed by the E key yields an with an acute accent.

The application can assume that certain keys will always return the same raw keycode, these keys do not have to be mapped. In general these keys are in the high part of the keymap, above $40, and includes all non-alphanumeric keys. The fixed keys include the function keys, backspace, delete, help and cursor keys.

element.name: IDCMP_REQVERIFY
element.short: IDCMP class: Verify intuition is ready to render a requester

descr.p: Set this flag to allow the application to ensure it is prepared for Intuition to render a requester in the window. With this flag set, Intuition sends the application a message that a requester is pending, and then waits for the application to reply before drawing the requester in the window.

If several requesters open in the window, Intuition asks the application to verify only the first one. After that, Intuition assumes that all output is being held off until all the requesters are gone.

By setting the and flags, the application can track how many requesters are open in the window and when the last requester is cleared. Once all of the requesters are cleared from the window, it is safe to write to the window until another IDCMP_REQVERIFY is received.

element.name: IDCMP_REQCLEAR
element.short: IDCMP class: Requester is cleared
element.descr: Intuition sends an IDCMP_REQCLEAR message to the window each time a requester is cleared from that window.

element.name: IDCMP_MENUVERIFY
element.short: IDCMP class: Verify ready to show menu

descr.p: This is a special verification mode which allows the program to confirm that it is prepared to handle Intuition rendering, in this case, allowing menus to be drawn in the screen.

This is a special kind of verification, in that any window in the entire screen that has this flag set must respond before the menu operations may proceed. Also, the active window of the screen is allowed to cancel the menu operation. This is unique to IDCMP_MENUVERIFY. Refer to the "Intuition Menus" for a complete description.

element.name: IDCMP_NEWPREFS
element.short: IDCMP class: Preferences are changed

descr.p: IDCMP_NEWPREFS messages are sent when the system Preferences are changed by a call to SetPrefs(). The program can learn of these changes by setting this flag.
After receiving a message of class IDCMP_NEWPREFS, the application should call GetPrefs() to obtain a copy of the new Preferences.

Under the new Preferences scheme used an IDCMP_NEWPREFS message will not always be sent when the user changes a Preferences setting. Only Preferences values that can be modified by a call to SetPrefs(), will cause an IDCMP_NEWPREFS message to be sent. New Preferences items such as overscan or font settings rely on filesystem notification for monitoring changes.

This message type is broadcast to all IDCMP that have this flag set, not just to the active window. If the application has this flag set, it should be prepared to handle the event even if it is not active.

element.name: IDCMP_DISKINSERTED
element.short: IDCMP class: Floppy disk inserted
element.descr:
When the user inserts a floppy disk from any drive, Intuition will send one of these message types.
This message type is broadcast to all IDCMP that have this flag set, not just to the active window. If the application has this flag set, it should be prepared to handle the event even if it is not active.

element.name: IDCMP_DISKREMOVED
element.short: IDCMP class: Floppy disk removed
element.descr:
When the user removes a floppy disk from any drive, Intuition will send one of these message types.
This message type is broadcast to all IDCMP that have this flag set, not just to the active window. If the application has this flag set, it should be prepared to handle the event even if it is not active.

element.name: IDCMP_WBENCHMESSAGE
element.short: IDCMP class: private
element.descr: Special messages for Workbench, system use only.

element.name: IDCMP_ACTIVEWINDOW
element.short: IDCMP class: Window is activated

element.name: IDCMP_INACTIVEWINDOW
element.short: IDCMP class: Window is deactivated

element.name: IDCMP_DELTAMOVE
element.short: IDCMP class:

descr.p: IDCMP_DELTAMOVE is not a message type, and events will never be sent to the application with this IDCMP identifier. This flag is a modifier, which changes how mouse movements are reported. When this flag is set, mouse movements are sent as delta values rather than as absolute positions.
The deltas are the amount of change of the mouse position from the last reported position. If the mouse does not move, then the delta values will be zero.
This flag works in conjunction with the flag. When IDCMP_DELTAMOVE is set, messages will also have relative values, instead of the absolute window position of the mouse.

Delta mouse movements are reported even after the Intuition pointer has reached the limits of the display. That is, if the pointer has reached the edge of the display and the user continues to move the mouse in the same direction, the messages will continue to report changes in the mouse position even though the pointer is no longer moving.

element.name: IDCMP_VANILLAKEY
element.short: IDCMP class: keyboard events

descr.p: IDCMP_VANILLAKEY messages return keyboard events translated into the current default character keymap. The mapped character value is returned in the Code field.
An IDCMP_VANILLAKEY message is sent only if the translation results in a single byte value, therefore the program cannot read the Help or function keys using IDCMP_VANILLAKEY.

Programs using IDCMP_VANILLAKEY which also require the additional information of special keys, such as the Help key and the function keys, may set both IDCMP_VANILLAKEY and . When this combination is used, all keypresses that map to single character values will be returned as IDCMP_VANILLAKEY events; all other keyboard events will be sent as messages. Note that IDCMP_VANILLAKEY processing uses all of the key-up events, so the application will only receive key-down events in the format.

element.name: IDCMP_INTUITICKS
element.short: IDCMP Class: Time ticks

descr.p: Intuition sends these messages to the active window based on an internal timer which "ticks" roughly ten times a second. This provides the application with simple timer events from Intuition.

Intuition does not allow IDCMP_INTUITICKS events to accumulate at a port. After an IDCMP_INTUITICKS message has been sent to a port, Intuition will not send another until the application replies to the first. This means that an application that has not been able to service the IDCMP for an extended period can expect at most one IDCMP_INTUITICKS message to be waiting at the port.

These events are to be used as "prods", and not as time counters. Do not rely on the timing accuracy of the event, or on the exact frequency at which they appear. Remember, IDCMP_INTUITICKS will only be sent to the active window. If the user selects another window, the events will no longer be received at the first window.

element.name: IDCMP_IDCMPUPDATE
element.short: IDCMP Class: gadget notification
element.descr: Used for notification from Boopsi custom gadgets. The IAddress field contains a pointer to a tag item list.

element.name: IDCMP_MENUHELP
element.short: IDCMP Class: Help key pressed

descr.p: This message is sent by Intuition when the user selects the Help key while the menu system is activated. If a menu item was selected, the menu number of the menu item can be found in the Code field. If no item was selected, the Code field will be equal to .
These messages will only be sent if the attribute is set for the window.

The menu number returned in IDCMP_MENUHELP may specify a position that cannot be generated through normal menu activity. For instance, the menu number may indicate one of the menu headers with no item or sub-item.

element.name: IDCMP_CHANGEWINDOW
element.short: IDCMP class: Window changed size or position
element.descr: This message provides the window with notification of any change in the size or position of a window.

element.name: WA_Dummy
element.short: Starting for window TagItems

element.name: WA_Left
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). The initial x position

descr.p: Describe where the window will first appear on the screen and how large it will be initially. These dimensions are relative to the top left corner of the screen, which has the coordinates (0,0).
WA_Left is the initial x position, or offset, from the left edge of the screen. The leftmost pixel is pixel 0, and values increase to the right. Equivalent to .LeftEdge.

element.name: WA_Top
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). The initial y position

descr.p: Describe where the window will first appear on the screen and how large it will be initially. These dimensions are relative to the top left corner of the screen, which has the coordinates (0,0).
WA_Top is the initial y position, or offset, from the top edge of the screen. The topmost pixel is pixel 0, and values increase to the bottom. Equivalent to .TopEdge.

element.name: WA_Width
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). The initial window width in pixels
element.descr: Equivalent to .Width

element.name: WA_Height
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). The initial window height in pixels
element.descr: Equivalent to .Height

element.name: WA_DetailPen
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). Specifies the pen number for the rendering of window details like gadgets or text in the title bar.
element.descr: Equivalent to .DetailPen The specific color associated with each pen number depends on the screen. Specifying -1 for these values sets the window's detail and block pen the same as the screen's detail and block pen.

element.name: WA_BlockPen
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). Specifies the pen number for window block fills, like the title bar.
element.descr: Equivalent to .BlockPen The specific color associated with each pen number depends on the screen. Specifying -1 for these values sets the window's detail and block pen the same as the screen's detail and block pen.

element.name: WA_IDCMP
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). Which events should be reported

descr.p: IDCMP flags tell Intuition what user input events the application wants to be notified about. (see IDCMP_*) Equivalent to .IDCMPFlags

If any of these flags are set, Intuition creates a pair of message ports for the window (one internal to Intuition and one used by the application). These ports are for handling messages about user input events. If WA_IDCMP is nil or unspecified, no IDCMP is created for this window.
The ModifyIDCMP() function can be used to change the window's IDCMP flags after it is open.

element.name: WA_Flags
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). Window Flags (WFLG_*)
element.descr: Multiple initialization of window flags, equivalent to .Flags. Use the WFLG_* constants to initialize this field, multiple bits may be set by ORing the values together.

element.name: WA_Gadgets
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). List of Gadgets
element.descr: A pointer to the first in the linked list of Gadget structures that are to be included in this window. These gadgets are application gadgets, not system gadgets. Equivalent to .FirstGadget

element.name: WA_Checkmark
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). Image for Menu entries
element.descr: A pointer to an Image structure, which is to be used as the checkmark image in this window's menus. To use the default checkmark, do not specify this tag or set this field to nil. Equivalent to .CheckMark

element.name: WA_Title
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). Title for window

descr.p: A pointer to a #0 terminated text string, which is used as the window title and is displayed in the window's title bar.

Intuition draws the text using the colors defined in the DrawInfo pen array (TDrawInfo.dri_Pens) and displays as much as possible of the window title, depending upon the current width of the title bar.
The title is rendered in the screen's default font.

A title bar is added to the window if any of the properties (), (), () or are specified, or if text is specified for a window title. If no text is provided for the title, but one or more of these system gadgets are specified, the title bar will be blank. Equivalent to .Title.

element.name: WA_ScreenTitle
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). Title for screen when window is activated
element.descr: A pointer to a #0 terminated text string, which is used as the screen title and is displayed, when the window is active, in the screen's title bar. After the screen has been opened the screen's title may be changed by calling SetWindowTitles().

element.name: WA_CustomScreen
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). Open the window on a specific screen
element.descr: A pointer to the Screen structure of a screen created by this application. The window will be opened on this screen. The custom screen must already be opened when the OpenWindowTagList() call is made. Equivalent to NewWindow.Screen, also implies .Type of .

element.name: WA_SuperBitMap
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). SuperBitmap for scrolling windows
element.descr: This is a pointer to a BitMap structure for a SuperBitMap window. The application will be allocating and maintaining its own bitmap. Equivalent to .BitMap. Setting this tag implies the property.

element.name: WA_MinWidth
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). Minimum width for resizeable windows

descr.p: This tag set the minimum value to which the user may size the window. If the flag is not set, then these variables are ignored.
Setting this variable to 0, will take the setting for that dimension from its initial value.
Equivalent to .MinWidth Use the WindowLimits() function to change window size limits after the window is opened.

element.name: WA_MinHeight
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). Minimum height for resizeable windows

descr.p: This tag set the minimum value to which the user may size the window. If the flag is not set, then these variables are ignored.
Setting this variable to 0, will take the setting for that dimension from its initial value.
Equivalent to .MinHeight Use the WindowLimits() function to change window size limits after the window is opened.

element.name: WA_MaxWidth
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). Maximum width for resizeable windows

descr.p: This tag set the minimum value to which the user may size the window. If the flag is not set, then these variables are ignored. Values are measured in pixels. Use -1 for this value to allow for a window as wide as the screen. This is the complete screen, not the visible part or display clip.
Setting this variable to 0, will take the setting for that dimension from its initial value.
Equivalent to .MaxWidth Use the WindowLimits() function to change window size limits after the window is opened.

element.name: WA_MaxHeight
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). Minimum height for resizeable windows

descr.p: This tag set the minimum value to which the user may size the window. If the flag is not set, then these variables are ignored. Values are measured in pixels. Use -1 for this value to allow for a window as tall as the screen. This is the complete screen, not the visible part or display clip.
Setting this variable to 0, will take the setting for that dimension from its initial value.
Equivalent to .MaxHeight Use the WindowLimits() function to change window size limits after the window is opened.

element.name: WA_InnerWidth
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). Inner width for the window

descr.p: Specify the dimensions of the interior region of the window, i.e., inside the border, independent of the border widths. When using this flag an application will probably want to set .

element.name: WA_InnerHeight
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). Inner height of window

descr.p: Specify the dimensions of the interior region of the window, i.e., inside the border, independent of the border widths. When using this flag an application will probably want to set .

element.name: WA_PubScreenName
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). Choose screen by name

descr.p: Declares that the window is to be opened as a visitor on the public screen whose name is pointed to by the ti_Data field of the WA_PubScreenName TagItem. The OpenWindowTagList() call will fail if it cannot obtain a lock on the named public screen and no fall back name () is specified. Setting this tag implies screen type of .

element.name: WA_PubScreen
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). Specify screen to open window on

descr.p: Open the window as a visitor window on the public screen whose address is in the ti_Data field of the WA_PubScreen TagItem. To ensure that this screen remains open until OpenWindowTagList() has completed, the application must either be the screen's owner, have a window open on the screen, or use LockPubScreen(). Setting this tag implies screen type of .

element.name: WA_PubScreenFallBack
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). Fallback screen to default
element.descr: A Boolean, specifies whether a visitor window should "fall back" to the default public screen (or Workbench) if the named public screen isn't available This tag is only meaningful when used in conjunction with .

element.name: WA_WindowName
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList().

element.name: WA_Colors
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList().
element.descr: A ColorSpec array for colors to be set when this window is active. This is not implemented, and may not be, since the default values to restore would be hard to track. We'd like to at least support per-window colors for the mouse pointer sprite.

element.name: WA_Zoom
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). Define zoom size for window

descr.p: Pointer to an array of four SmallInts, the initial LeftEdge, TopEdge, Width and Height values for the alternate zoom position and size. It also specifies that the application wants a zoom gadget for the window, whether or not it has a sizing gadget.

A zoom gadget is always supplied to a window if it has both depth and sizing gadgets. This tag allows the application to open a window with a zoom gadget when the window does not have both the depth and sizing gadgets.

element.name: WA_MouseQueue
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). Mouse event queue size
element.descr: An initial value for the mouse message backlog limit for this window. The SetMouseQueue() function will change this limit after the window is opened.

element.name: WA_BackFill
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). BackFill hook
element.descr: Provides a "backfill hook" for your window's layer.

element.name: WA_RptQueue
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). Key event queue size
element.descr: An initial value of repeat key backlog limit for this window.

element.name: WA_SizeGadget
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList().
element.descr: Specifying this flag tells Intuition to add a sizing gadget to the window. Intuition places the sizing gadget in the lower right corner of the window. By default, the right border is adjusted to accommodate the sizing gadget, but the application can specify one of the following two flags to change this behavior. The flag puts the sizing gadget in the right border. The flag puts the sizing gadget in the bottom border. Both flags may be specified, placing the gadget in both borders. Equivalent to .Flags with set .

element.name: WA_DragBar
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). Titlebar used to drag window
element.descr: This flag turns the entire title bar of the window into a drag gadget, allowing the user to position the window by clicking in the title bar and dragging the mouse. Equivalent to .Flags with set .

element.name: WA_DepthGadget
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). Add Depthgadget to window
element.descr: Setting this flag adds a depth gadget to the window. This allows the user to change the window's depth arrangement with respect to other windows on the screen. Intuition places the depth gadget in the upper right corner of the window. Equivalent to .Flags with set .

element.name: WA_CloseGadget
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). Add CloseGadget to window
element.descr: Setting this flag attaches a close gadget to the window. When the user selects this gadget, Intuition transmits a message to the application. It is up to the application to close the window with a CloseWindow() call. Intuition places the close gadget in the upper left corner of the window. Equivalent to .Flags with set .

element.name: WA_Backdrop
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). Make this window a backdrop window
element.descr: Make this window a Backdrop window. Equivalent to .Flags with set .

element.name: WA_ReportMouse
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). Report mouse events

descr.p: Send mouse movement events to the window as x,y coordinates. Also see the description of the IDCMP flag . Equivalent to .Flags with set .

The WFLG_REPORTMOUSE flag in the Flags field of the Window structure may be modified on the fly by the program. Changing this flag must be done as an atomic operation. If you are unsure of getting an atomic operation from your compiler, you may wish to do this operation in assembler, or bracket the code with a Forbid()/Permit() pair.
The use of the ReportMouse() function is strongly discouraged, due to historic confusion over the parameter ordering.

element.name: WA_NoCareRefresh
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). Do not need Refresh message
element.descr: This window does not want events. Set this flag to prevent the window from receiving refresh window messages. Equivalent to .Flags with set . Intuition will manage BeginRefresh() and EndRefresh() internally.

element.name: WA_Borderless
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). Make window borderless

descr.p: Open a window with no borders rendered by Intuition. Equivalent to .Flags with set .

Use caution setting this flag, as it may cause visual confusion on the screen. Also, some borders may be rendered if any of the system gadgets are requested, if text is supplied for the window's title bar, or if any of application gadgets are in the borders.

element.name: WA_Activate
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). Activate the window when it opens.
element.descr: Activate the window when it opens. Equivalent to .Flags with set . Use this flag carefully, as it can change where the user's input is going.

element.name: WA_RMBTrap
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList().

descr.p: Catch right mouse button events for application use. Set this flag to disable menu operations for the window. When set, right mouse button events will be received as with the and qualifiers. Equivalent to .Flags with set .

The flag in the Window structure Flags field may be modified on the fly by the program. Changing this flag must be done as an atomic operation, as Intuition can preempt a multistep set or clear operation. An atomic operation can be done in assembler, using instructions that operate directly on memory. If you are unsure of generating such an instruction, place the operation within a Forbid()/Permit() pair. This will ensure proper operation by disabling multitasking while the flag is being changed.

element.name: WA_WBenchWindow
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). Private
element.descr: Private tag

element.name: WA_SimpleRefresh
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList().
element.descr: The application program takes complete responsibility for updating the window. Only specify if True. Equivalent to .Flags with set .

element.name: WA_SmartRefresh
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList().

descr.p: Intuition handles all window updating, except for parts of the window revealed when the window is sized larger. Only specify if True. Equivalent to .Flags with set .

WA_SmartRefresh windows without a sizing gadget will never receive refresh events due to the user sizing the window. However, if the application sizes the window through a call like ChangeWindowBox(), ZipWindow() or SizeWindow(), a refresh event may be generated. Use to disable refresh events.

element.name: WA_SizeBRight
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). Place the size gadget in the right border.
element.descr: Place the size gadget in the right border. Equivalent to .Flags with set .

element.name: WA_SizeBBottom
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). Place the size gadget in the bottom border.
element.descr: Place the size gadget in the bottom border. Equivalent to .Flags with set .

element.name: WA_AutoAdjust
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList().Auto adjust window size to screen maximum.
element.descr: Allow Intuition to change the window's position and dimensions in order to fit it on screen. The window's position is adjusted first, then the size. This property may be especially important when using and as border size depends on a user specified font.

element.name: WA_GimmeZeroZero
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). Zero-Zero window
element.descr: Set this tag to create a GimmeZeroZero window. GimmeZeroZero windows have the window border and border gadgets rendered into an extra layer. This extra layer slows down window operations, thus it is recommended that applications only use GimmeZeroZero windows when they are required. For clipping graphics to the area within the borders of a window. Equivalent to .Flags with set .

element.name: WA_MenuHelp
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). Enabled Help button for Menu
element.descr: Enables : pressing Help during menus will return message.

element.name: WA_NewLookMenus
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). Activate NewLook menus
element.descr: Set to True if you want NewLook menus.

element.name: WA_AmigaKey
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). Amiga key image for Menus
element.descr: Pointer to image for Amiga-key equiv in menus

element.name: WA_NotifyDepth
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList().
element.descr: Requests message when window is depth arranged (imsg^.Code = )

element.name: WA_Pointer
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). Custom Pointer for window.
element.descr: Allows you to specify a custom pointer for your window. ti_Data points to a pointer object you obtained via "pointerclass". Nil signifies the default pointer. This tag may be passed to OpenWindowTagList() or SetWindowPointerA().

element.name: WA_BusyPointer
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). Request standard busy pointer
element.descr: ti_Data is a boolean. Set to True to request the standard busy pointer. This tag may be passed to OpenWindowTagList() or SetWindowPointerA().

element.name: WA_PointerDelay
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). Delay of pointer change
element.descr: ti_Data is a boolean. Set to True to request that the changing of the pointer be slightly delayed. The change will be called off if you call SetPointer() before the delay expires. This allows you to post a busy-pointer even if you think the busy-time may be very short, without fear of a flashing pointer. This tag may be passed to OpenWindowTagList() or SetWindowPointerA().

element.name: WA_TabletMessages
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). Enabled tablet messages
element.descr: ti_Data is a boolean. Set to True to request that tablet information be included in sent to your window. For a pointer to the TabletData, examine the ExtIntuiMessage^.eim_TabletData field.

element.name: WA_HelpGroup
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). Form Help groups
element.descr: When the active window has gadget help enabled, other windows of the same HelpGroup number will also get GadgetHelp. This allows GadgetHelp to work for multi-windowed applications. Pass the ID as ti_Data to all your windows.

element.name: WA_HelpGroupWindow
element.short: Tag for OpenWindowTagList(). Form Help group windows
element.descr: When the active window has gadget help enabled, other windows of the same HelpGroup will also get GadgetHelp. This allows GadgetHelp to work for multi-windowed applications. As an alternative to , you can pass a pointer to any other window of the same group to join its help group. Defaults to nil, which has no effect.

element.name: WFLG_SIZEGADGET
element.short: Flag for or .Flags. Include sizing system-gadget

element.name: WFLG_DRAGBAR
element.short: Flag for or .Flags. Include dragging system-gadget

element.name: WFLG_DEPTHGADGET
element.short: Flag for or .Flags. Include depth arrangement gadget

element.name: WFLG_CLOSEGADGET
element.short: Flag for or .Flags. Include close-box system-gadget

element.name: WFLG_SIZEBRIGHT
element.short: Flag for or .Flags. Size gadget uses right border

element.name: WFLG_SIZEBBOTTOM
element.short: Flag for or .Flags. Size gadget uses bottom border

element.name: WFLG_SMART_REFRESH
element.short: Flag for or .Flags. Enable smart Refresh

element.name: WFLG_SIMPLE_REFRESH
element.short: Flag for or .Flags. Enable Simple Refresh

element.name: WFLG_SUPER_BITMAP
element.short: Flag for or .Flags. Has super bitmap

element.name: WFLG_OTHER_REFRESH
element.short: Flag for or .Flags. Simple refresh and super bitmap

element.name: WFLG_REFRESHBITS
element.short: Flag for or .Flags. Simple refresh and super bitmap

element.name: WFLG_BACKDROP
element.short: Flag for or .Flags. This is a backdrop window

element.name: WFLG_REPORTMOUSE
element.short: Flag for or .Flags. Fire an event for every mouse move

element.name: WFLG_GIMMEZEROZERO
element.short: Flag for or .Flags. A GimmeZeroZero window

element.name: WFLG_BORDERLESS
element.short: Flag for or .Flags. Get a window sans border.

element.name: WFLG_ACTIVATE
element.short: Flag for or .Flags. When window opens, it is active.

element.name: WFLG_WINDOWACTIVE
element.short: Flag for or .Flags. Private. This window is the active one.

element.name: WFLG_INREQUEST
element.short: Flag for or .Flags. Private. This window is in request mode.

element.name: WFLG_MENUSTATE
element.short: Flag for or .Flags. Private. Window is active with menus on.

element.name: WFLG_RMBTRAP
element.short: Flag for or .Flags. Fire right mouse button events

element.name: WFLG_NOCAREREFRESH
element.short: Flag for or .Flags. Not to be bothered with REFRESH

element.name: WFLG_NW_EXTENDED
element.short: Flag for .Flags. Extension data provided see .

element.name: WFLG_NEWLOOKMENUS
element.short: Flag for or .Flags. Window has NewLook menus.

element.name: WFLG_WINDOWREFRESH
element.short: Flag for .Flags. Window is currently refreshing

element.name: WFLG_WBENCHWINDOW
element.short: Flag for .Flags. Workbench tool only Window

element.name: WFLG_WINDOWTICKED
element.short: Flag for .Flags. Only one timer tick at a time

element.name: WFLG_VISITOR
element.short: Flag for .Flags. Visitor window.

element.name: WFLG_ZOOMED
element.short: Flag for .Flags. Identifies "Zoom State"

element.name: WFLG_HASZOOM
element.short: Flag for .Flags. Window has a zoom gadget.

element.name: DEFAULTMOUSEQUEUE
element.short: Window value, No more mouse messaged

element.name: HC_GADGETHELP
element.short: Flag for HelpControl() Set this flag to enable Gadget-Help for one or more windows.

element.name: POINTREL
element.short: Flag for .Flags. If set TopLeft is relative to pointer to the coordinates of either the pointer or the window.

element.name: PREDRAWN
element.short: Flag for .Flags. If set, ImageBMap points to a custom bitmap.

element.name: NOISYREQ
element.short: Flag for .Flags. Requester does not filter input.

element.name: SIMPLEREQ
element.short: Flag for .Flags. If set, a SIMPLEREFRESH layer is used.

element.name: USEREQIMAGE
element.short: Flag for .Flags. Render linked list ReqImage after BackFill but before gadgets and text

element.name: NOREQBACKFILL
element.short: Flag for .Flags. Don't bother filling requester with .BackFill pen

element.name: REQOFFWINDOW
element.short: Flag for .Flags. Read-Only. Part of one of the Gadgets was offwindow

element.name: REQACTIVE
element.short: Flag for .Flags. Read-Only. This requester is active

element.name: SYSREQUEST
element.short: Flag for .Flags. Read-Only. This requester caused by system

element.name: DEFERREFRESH
element.short: Flag for .Flags. Read-Only. This Requester stops a Refresh broadcast

element.name: TABLETA_Dummy
element.short: Tablet Tag Base

element.name: TABLETA_TabletZ
element.short: Tag for .td_TagList. The current value of the tablet in the Z direction.
element.descr: The current value of the tablet in the Z direction. This unsigned value should typically be in the natural units of the tablet. You should also provide .

element.name: TABLETA_RangeZ
element.short: Tag for .td_TagList. The maximum value of the tablet in the Z direction.
element.descr: The maximum value of the tablet in the Z direction. Normally specified along with , this allows the application to scale the actual Z value across its range.

element.name: TABLETA_AngleX
element.short: Tag for .td_TagList. The angle of rotation or tilt about the X-axis.
element.descr: The angle of rotation or tilt about the X-axis. This number should be normalized to fill a signed long LongInt. Positive values imply a clockwise rotation about the X-axis when viewing from +X towards the origin.

element.name: TABLETA_AngleY
element.short: Tag for .td_TagList. The angle of rotation or tilt about the Y-axis.
element.descr: The angle of rotation or tilt about the Y-axis. This number should be normalized to fill a signed long LongInt. Positive values imply a clockwise rotation about the Y-axis when viewing from +Y towards the origin.

element.name: TABLETA_AngleZ
element.short: Tag for .td_TagList. The angle of rotation or tilt about the Z axis.
element.descr: The angle of rotation or tilt about the Z axis. This number should be normalized to fill a signed long LongInt. Positive values imply a clockwise rotation about the Z-axis when viewing from +Z towards the origin.

element.name: TABLETA_Pressure
element.short: Tag for .td_TagList. The pressure reading of the stylus.
element.descr: The pressure reading of the stylus. The pressure should be normalized to fill a signed long LongInt. Typical devices won't generate negative pressure, but the possibility is not precluded. The pressure threshold which is considered to cause a button-click is expected to be set in a Preferences program supplied by the tablet vendor. The tablet driver would send -type events as the pressure crossed that threshold.

element.name: TABLETA_ButtonBits
element.short: Tag for .td_TagList. Button States
element.descr: ti_Data is a long LongInt whose bits are to be interpreted at the state of the first 32 buttons of the tablet.

element.name: TABLETA_InProximity
element.short: Tag for .td_TagList. For tablets that support proximity,
element.descr: ti_Data is a boolean. For tablets that support proximity, they should send the (, False) tag item when the stylus is out of proximity. One possible use we can forsee is a mouse-blanking commodity which keys off this to blank the mouse. When this tag is absent, the stylus is assumed to be in proximity.

element.name: TABLETA_ResolutionX
element.short: Tag for .td_TagList. X-axis resolution
element.descr: ti_Data is an unsigned long LongInt which is the x-axis resolution in dots per inch.

element.name: TABLETA_ResolutionY
element.short: Tag for .td_TagList. Y-axis resolution
element.descr: ti_Data is an unsigned long LongInt which is the y-axis resolution in dots per inch.

element.name: PRemember
element.short: Pointer to Memory allocating remember structure

element.name: TRemember
element.short: Structure to remember memory allocations
element.descr: This structure is used for remembering what memory has been allocated to date by a given routine, so that a premature abort or systematic exit can deallocate memory cleanly, easily, and completely

element.name: TRemember.NextRemember
element.short: Next memory block in List

element.name: TRemember.RememberSize
element.short: Size of Memory Block

element.name: TRemember.Memory
element.short: Pointer to the allocated memory

element.name: PColorSpec
element.short: Pointer to Color table entry

element.name: TColorSpec
element.short: Color table entry

element.name: TColorSpec.ColorIndex
element.short: -1 terminates an array of ColorSpec

element.name: TColorSpec.Red
element.short: Only the bottom 4 bits recognized

element.name: TColorSpec.Green
element.short: Only the bottom 4 bits recognized

element.name: TColorSpec.Blue
element.short: Only the bottom 4 bits recognized

element.name: PEasyStruct
element.short: The text and setup of an easy requester

element.name: TEasyStruct
element.short: The text and setup of an easy requester

element.name: TEasyStruct.es_StructSize
element.short: should be sizeof (TEasyStruct) Note that this size may change, if you update the includes! Do not use absolute values as the size of pointers may vary on different platforms!

element.name: TEasyStruct.es_Flags
element.short: should be 0 for now

element.name: TEasyStruct.es_Title
element.short: Title of easy requester window. If this is nil, the title will be taken to be the same as the title of the reference window, if one is specified in the EasyRequestArgs() call, else the title will be "System Request".

element.name: TEasyStruct.es_TextFormat
element.short: 'printf' style formatting string see RawDoFmt()

element.name: TEasyStruct.es_GadgetFormat
element.short: Text of the gadgets, separated by '|' (vertical bar) support no further formating. At least one gadget must be specified.

element.name: ALERT_TYPE
element.short: Alert Type for DisplayAlert()

element.name: RECOVERY_ALERT
element.short: Alert Type for DisplayAlert() the system can recover from this

element.name: DEADEND_ALERT
element.short: Alert Type for DisplayAlert() no recovery possible, this is it

element.name: SELECTDOWN
element.short: RawMouse code for .Code. Left Mouse Button down.

element.name: SELECTUP
element.short: RawMouse code for .Code. Left Mouse Button up.

element.name: MENUDOWN
element.short: RawMouse code for .Code. Right Mouse Button down.

element.name: MENUUP
element.short: RawMouse code for .Code. Right Mouse Button up.

element.name: MIDDLEDOWN
element.short: RawMouse code for .Code. Middle Mouse Button down.

element.name: MIDDLEUP
element.short: RawMouse code for .Code. Middle Mouse Button up.

element.descr: The DrawInfo structure provides information Intuition uses to support the 3D look and specifies graphical information for applications that use the screen. The information includes such items as aspect ratio (resolution), font, number of colors and drawing pens.

element.name: TDrawInfo.dri_Pens

element.name: TDrawInfo.dri_Font

element.name: TDrawInfo.dri_Resolution

element.name: SA_Dummy
element.short: Tag start for OpenScreenTagList() Tags

element.name: SA_Left
element.short: Tag start for OpenScreenTagList() eqivalent to .LeftEdge

descr.p: Initial screen position (left edge). Data is a LongInt, signed value. Offsets are relative to the text overscan rectangle.

If SA_Left is not specified and a structure is not passed in the OpenScreenTagList() call and is not specified or is specified as , then the left edge of the screen will default to the left edge of the actual display clip of the screen. If the other conditions are met but some explicit SA_Width is specified, then the left edge defaults to zero (text overscan rectangle left edge). Likewise, the top edge may, independent of the left edge value, default to zero or to the top edge of the actual display clip.

When opening a full sized overscan screen, SA_Left should be set to the MinX value of the display clip Rectangle used for the screen and This may be taken from the defaults, as explained above, or explicitly set by the application.
If your screen is larger than your display clip, you may wish to set the SA_Left to a value less than your display clip MinX in order to center a large screen on a smaller display.

element.name: SA_Top
element.short: Tag start for OpenScreenTagList() eqivalent to .TopEdge

descr.p: Initial screen position (top edge). Data is a LongInt, signed value. Offsets are relative to the text overscan rectangle.

If SA_Top is not specified and a structure is not passed in the OpenScreenTagList() call and is not specified or specified as , then the top edge of the screen will default to the top edge of the actual display clip of the screen. If the other conditions are met but some explicit SA_Height is specified, then the top edge defaults to zero (text overscan rectangle top edge).
When opening a full sized overscan screen, SA_Top should be set to the MinY value of the display clip. This may be taken from the defaults, as explained above, or explicitly set by the application.
If your screen is larger than your display clip, you may wish to set the SA_Top to a value less than your display clip MinY in order to center a large screen on a smaller display.

element.name: SA_Width
element.short: Tag start for OpenScreenTagList() eqivalent to .Width

descr.p: Screen dimensions. Data is a LongWord. These may be larger, smaller or the same as the dimensions of the display clip Rectangle. The use of will make the screen size equal to the display clip size.

To calculate the width of the display clip Rectangle, subtract the MinX value from the MaxX value plus one. Similarly, the height of the display clip may be calculated by subtracting the MinY value from the MaxY value plus one.

element.name: SA_Height
element.short: Tag start for OpenScreenTagList() eqivalent to .Height

descr.p: Screen dimensions. Data is a LongWord. These may be larger, smaller or the same as the dimensions of the display clip Rectangle. The use of will make the screen size equal to the display clip size.

To calculate the width of the display clip Rectangle, subtract the MinX value from the MaxX value plus one. Similarly, the height of the display clip may be calculated by subtracting the MinY value from the MaxY value plus one.

element.name: SA_Depth
element.short: Tag start for OpenScreenTagList() Screen bitmap depth

descr.p: Screen bitmap depth. Data is a LongWord. The depth of the screen determines the number of available colors. Do not set the depth to a value greater than that supported by the specific display mode. This information is available to the application through the graphics library display database. The default is one bitplane.

element.name: SA_DetailPen
element.short: Tag start for OpenScreenTagList() serves as default for windows, too
element.descr: Detail pen for the screen. Data is a long, unsigned value. Used for rendering details in the screen title bar and menus. Use for more control of pen specification. If is not specified, the screen will not get the new 3D look of Intuition. Instead this value will be used as the detail pen.

element.name: SA_BlockPen
element.short: Tag start for OpenScreenTagList() serves as default for windows, too
element.descr: Block pen for the screen. Data is a long, unsigned value. Used for rendering block fills in the screen title bar and menus. Use for more control of pen specification. If is not specified, the screen will not get the new 3D look and this value will be used as the block pen.

element.name: SA_Title
element.short: Tag start for OpenScreenTagList() default screen title
element.descr: Default screen title. Data is a pointer to a character string. This is the title displayed when the active window has no screen title or when no window is active on the screen.

element.name: SA_Colors
element.short: Tag start for OpenScreenTagList() ti_Data is an array of , terminated by ColorIndex = -1. Specifies initial screen palette colors.
element.descr: Specifies initial screen palette colors. Data is a pointer to an array of structures, terminated by a ColorSpec structure with ColorIndex=-1. Screen colors may be changed after the screen is opened with the graphics library functions SetRGB4() and LoadRGB4(). ColorSpec colors are right-justified, four bits per gun.

element.name: SA_ErrorCode
element.short: Tag start for OpenScreenTagList() ti_Data points to LongInt error code
element.descr: Extended error code. Data is a pointer to a LongInt which will contain the error code on return if OpenScreenTagList() returns nil. The error codes are described above.

element.name: SA_Font
element.short: Tag start for OpenScreenTagList() equiv. to .Font
element.descr: Data is a pointer to a structure which specifies the font, size and style to use for the screen. Equivalent to .Font.

element.name: SA_SysFont
element.short: Tag start for OpenScreenTagList() Selects one of the preferences system fonts: 0 - old DefaultFont, fixed-width 1 - WB Screen preferred font

descr.p: Alternative to . Selects one of the preferences system fonts. Data is a LongWord, with the following values defined:

dl.dd: Open screen with the user's preferred fixed width font (the default).
Open screen with the user's preferred font, which may be proportional.

descr.p: The Workbench screen is opened with [, 1]. Table summarizes how the font selected at OpenScreen() time effects subsequent text operations in screens and windows.

ul.li: A and B are the options that existed in V34 and earlier OS versions.
C and D are tags in Release 2 equivalent to A and B respectively.
E is a new option for V36. The Workbench screen uses this option.
For `myfont', any font may be used including a proportional one. This is true under all releases of the OS.
.DefaultFont is always monospace. (This is the "System Default Text" from Font Preferences.)
Font Prefs Screen text (the "Screen Text" choice from Font Preferences) can be monospace or proportional.

descr.p: The screen's font may not legally be changed after a screen is opened. The menu bar, window titles, menu items, and the contents of a string gadget all use the screen's font. The font used for menu items can be overridden in the menu item's IntuiText structure. Under V36 and higher, the font used in a string gadget can be overridden through the StringExtend structure. The font of the menu bar and window titles cannot be overridden.

The Window.RPort font shown above is the initial font that Intuition sets in your window's RastPort. It is legal to change that subsequently with SetFont(). IntuiText rendered into a window (either through PrintIText() or as a .GadgetText) defaults to the window's RastPort font, but can be overridden using its .TITextFont field. Text rendered with the graphics library call GfxText() uses the window's RastPort font.

element.name: SA_Type
element.short: Tag start for OpenScreenTagList() equiv. to .SType
element.descr: Equivalent to the bits of the .SType field. Data is a LongWord, which may be set to either or ( is reserved for system use). See the tags , , , and for the other attributes of the .SType field.

element.name: SA_BitMap
element.short: Tag start for OpenScreenTagList() ti_Data is pointer to custom BitMap. This implies TNewScreen.SType of
element.descr: Use a custom bitmap for this screen. Data is a . This tag is equivalent to .CustomBitMap and implies the flag of the NewScreen.Type field. The application is responsible for allocating and freeing the screen's bitmap.

element.name: SA_PubName
element.short: Tag start for OpenScreenTagList() Presence of this tag means that the screen is to be a public screen. Please specify before and
element.descr: Presence of this tag means that the screen is to be a public screen. Data is a PChar. The string is the name of the public screen which is used by other applications to find the screen. This tag is order dependent, specify before and .

element.name: SA_PubSig
element.short: Tag start for OpenScreenTagList()
element.descr: Signal for notification that the last window has closed on a public screen. Data is a LongWord. This tag is order dependent, and must be specified after the tag .

element.name: SA_PubTask
element.short: Tag start for OpenScreenTagList() Task ID and signal for being notified that the last window has closed on a public screen.
element.descr: Task (returned by FindTask()) notification that the last window has closed on a public screen. Data is a long, unsigned value. Data is a pointer to a structure. This tag is order dependent, and must be specified after the tag .

element.name: SA_DisplayID
element.short: Tag start for OpenScreenTagList() ti_Data is new extended display ID

element.name: SA_DClip
element.short: Tag start for OpenScreenTagList() ti_Data points to a rectangle which defines screen display clip region
element.descr: Custom display clip specification. Data is a pointer to a Rectangle structure that defines the screen display clip region.

element.name: SA_Overscan
element.short: Tag start for OpenScreenTagList() Set Overscan defaults to
element.descr: Set to one of the OSCAN_* specifiers to get a system standard verscan region for your display clip, screen dimensions (unless otherwise specified), and automatically centered position (partial support only so far). If you use this, you shouldn't specify . SA_Overscan is for "standard" overscan dimensions, is for your custom numeric specifications.

element.name: SA_ShowTitle
element.short: Tag start for OpenScreenTagList() boolean equivalent to flag

descr.p: Setting this flag places the screen's title bar in front of any backdrop windows that are opened on the screen. Data is a boolean value (True to set flag). This tag is equivalent to the flag of the .SType field. The title bar of the screen is always displayed behind any non-backdrop windows on that screen. This attribute can be changed after the screen is open with the ShowTitle() function.

element.name: SA_Behind
element.short: Tag start for OpenScreenTagList() boolean equivalent to flag
element.descr: Open this screen behind all other screens in the system. Data is a boolean value (True to set flag). This tag is equivalent to the flag of the NewScreen.Type field.

element.name: SA_Quiet
element.short: Tag start for OpenScreenTagList() boolean equivalent to flag
element.descr: Disable Intuition rendering into screen. Data is a boolean value (True to set flag). This tag is equivalent to the flag of the .SType field. The screen will have no visible title bar or gadgets, but dragging and depth arrangement still function. In order to completely prevent Intuition from rendering into the screen, menu operations must be disabled for each window in the screen using .

element.name: SA_AutoScroll
element.short: Tag start for OpenScreenTagList() boolean equivalent to flag

descr.p: Setting this flag will enable autoscroll for this screen when it is the active screen. (Currently, the screen may only be made active by activating a window in that screen either under user or application control.) Data is a boolean value (True to set flag). This tag is equivalent to the flag of the .SType field.

Autoscroll means that screens larger than the visible display will automatically scroll when the user moves the mouse to the edge of the screen. Without this tag, the user moves the screen either by using the screen drag bar, or by pressing the mouse select button anywhere within the screen while holding down the left Amiga key and moving the mouse.

element.name: SA_Pens
element.short: Tag start for OpenScreenTagList() pointer to $FFFFFFFF terminated LongWord array, as found in
element.descr: Pen specification for the screen. Data is a pointer to a LongWord array terminated with $FFFFFFFF, as found in the DrawInfo structure. Specifying the SA_Pens tag informs the system that the application is prepared to handle a screen rendered with the new 3D look of Intuition. Omitting this tag produces a screen with a flat look, but whose color usage is more backwards compatible.

element.name: SA_FullPalette
element.short: Tag start for OpenScreenTagList() boolean: initialize color table to entire preferences palette, rather than compatible pens 0-3, 17-19, with remaining palette as returned by GetColorMap()

element.name: SA_ColorMapEntries
element.short: Tag start for OpenScreenTagList() Allows you to override the number of entries in the ColorMap for your screen.
element.descr: Intuition normally allocates ((1 shl depth) or 32), whichever is more, but you may require even more if you use certain graphics.library features (eg. palette-banking).

element.name: SA_Parent
element.short: Tag start for OpenScreenTagList() Pointer to a "parent" screen to attach this one to. Attached screens slide and depth-arrange together.

element.name: SA_Draggable
element.short: Tag start for OpenScreenTagList() Boolean tag allowing non-draggable screens. Do not use without good reason! (Defaults to True).

element.name: SA_Exclusive
element.short: Tag start for OpenScreenTagList() Boolean tag allowing screens that won't share the display. (Defaults to False)
element.descr: Use sparingly! Attached screens may be . Setting for each screen will produce an exclusive family.

element.name: SA_SharePens
element.short: Tag start for OpenScreenTagList() Allocate pens as shared
element.descr: For those pens in the screen's DrawInfo^.dri_Pens, Intuition obtains them in shared mode (see ObtainPen()). For compatibility, Intuition obtains the other pens of a public screen as PEN_EXCLUSIVE. Screens that wish to manage the pens themselves should generally set this tag to True. This instructs Intuition to leave the other pens unallocated.

element.name: SA_BackFill
element.short: Tag start for OpenScreenTagList() provides a "backfill hook" for your screen's TLayer_Info. See Layers.InstallLayerInfoHook()

element.name: SA_Interleaved
element.short: Tag start for OpenScreenTagList() Boolean tag requesting that the bitmap allocated for you be interleaved. (Defaults to False).

element.name: SA_Colors32
element.short: Tag start for OpenScreenTagList() set the screen's initial palette colors at 32 bits-per-gun.
element.descr: ti_Data is a pointer to a table to be passed to the LoadRGB32() function. This format supports both runs of color registers and sparse registers. See the autodoc for that function for full details. Any color set here has precedence over the same register set by .

element.name: SA_VideoControl
element.short: Tag start for OpenScreenTagList() Pointer to a taglist that Intuition will pass to VideoControl(), upon opening the screen.

element.name: SA_FrontChild
element.short: Tag start for OpenScreenTagList() Pointer to an already open screen that is to be the child of the screen being opened. The child screen will be moved to the front of its family.

element.name: SA_BackChild
element.short: Tag start for OpenScreenTagList() Pointer to an already open screen that is to be the child of the screen being opened. The child screen will be moved to the back of its family.

element.name: SA_LikeWorkbench
element.short: Tag start for OpenScreenTagList() 1 = request a screen which is just like the Workbench. This gives you the same screen mode, depth, size, colors, etc., as the Workbench screen.

element.name: SA_Reserved
element.short: Tag start for OpenScreenTagList() Reserved for private Intuition use

element.name: SA_MinimizeISG
element.short: Tag start for OpenScreenTagList() inter-screen gap is at least three non-interlaced lines
element.descr: For compatibility, Intuition always ensures that the inter-screen gap is at least three non-interlaced lines. If your application would look best with the smallest possible inter-screen gap, set ti_Data to True. If you use the VideoControl() VC_NoColorPaletteLoad tag for your screen's ViewPort, you should also set this tag.

element.name: NSTAG_EXT_VPMODE
element.short: this is an obsolete tag included only for compatibility with V35 interim release for the A2024 and Viking monitors

element.name: OSCAN_TEXT
element.short: Identifier for entirely visible

element.name: OSCAN_STANDARD
element.short: Identifier for just past edges

element.name: OSCAN_MAX
element.short: Identifier for as much as possible

element.name: OSCAN_VIDEO
element.short: Identifier for even more than is possible

element.name: PNewScreen
element.short: pointer to an instance of a NewScreen structure.

element.name: TNewScreen
element.short: Description of a new screen

element.name: TNewScreen.LeftEdge
element.short: initial position of your screen

element.name: TNewScreen.TopEdge
element.short: Left and Top are specified relative to the Intuition's view, in same resolution as the screen pixels.

element.name: TNewScreen.Width
element.short: the width for this screen's RastPort, or the constant to get the current default width

element.name: TNewScreen.Height
element.short: the height for his screen's RastPort, or the constant to get the current default height

element.name: TNewScreen.Depth
element.short: number of bitplanes

element.name: TNewScreen.DetailPen
element.short: pen number for details (like gadgets or text in title bar/border/gadget) The common value for this pen is 0.

element.name: TNewScreen.BlockPen
element.short: pen number for block fills (like title bar/border/gadget) The common value for this pen is 1.

element.name: TNewScreen.ViewModes
element.short: the Modes for the ViewPort (and View)

element.name: TNewScreen.SType
element.short: the Screen type , (Type in C-Include)

element.name: TNewScreen.Font
element.short: this Screen's default text attributes

element.name: TNewScreen.DefaultTitle
element.short: the default title for this Screen

element.name: TNewScreen.Gadgets
element.short: your own Gadgets for this Screen

element.name: TNewScreen.CustomBitMap
element.short: if you have your own display memory that you want used for this screen, the CustomBitMap field should point to the BitMap structure that describes your display memory.

element.name: PExtNewScreen
element.short: Pointer to Extended New Screen structure

element.name: TExtNewScreen
element.short: Extended structure

element.name: TExtNewScreen.LeftEdge
element.short: see at

element.name: TExtNewScreen.Extension
element.short: TExtNewScreen specific extension SA_*

element.name: PPubScreenNode
element.short: Pointer to Public Shared Screen Node

element.name: TPubScreenNode
element.short: Public Shared Screen Node
element.descr: This is the representative of a public shared screen. This is an internal data structure, but some functions may present a copy of it to the calling application. In that case, be aware that the screen pointer of the structure can NOT be used safely, since there is no guarantee that the referenced screen will remain open and a valid data structure. Never change one of these.

element.name: TPubScreenNode.psn_Node
element.short: ln_Name is screen name

element.name: TPubScreenNode.psn_Flags
element.short: Flags (PSNF_*)

element.name: TPubScreenNode.psn_Size
element.short: includes name buffer

element.name: TPubScreenNode.psn_VisitorCount
element.short: how many visitor windows

element.name: TPubScreenNode.psn_SigTask
element.short: who to signal when visitors gone

element.name: TPubScreenNode.psn_SigBit
element.short: which signal

element.name: PSNF_PRIVATE
element.short: Flag for .psn_Flags Private

element.name: MAXPUBSCREENNAME
element.short: Maximum length of public screen names. The buffers containing these strings must have a length of MAXPUBSCREENNAME + 1.

element.name: SHANGHAI
element.short: Pub Screen mode. put workbench windows on pub screen

element.name: POPPUBSCREEN
element.short: Pub screen mode. pop pub screen to front when visitor opens

element.name: SDEPTH_TOFRONT
element.short: Flag for ScreenDepth(). Bring screen to front

element.name: SDEPTH_TOBACK
element.short: Flag for ScreenDepth(). Send screen to back

element.name: SPOS_RELATIVE
element.short: Flag for ScreenPosition(). The x1 and y1 parameters to ScreenPosition() describe the offset in coordinates you wish to move the screen by. Coordinates are relative

element.name: SPOS_ABSOLUTE
element.short: Flag for ScreenPosition(). The x1 and y1 parameters to ScreenPosition() describe the absolute coordinates you wish to move the screen to. Coordinates are expressed as absolutes, not relatives.

element.name: SPOS_MAKEVISIBLE
element.short: Flag for ScreenPosition(). Coordinates describe a box on the screen you wish to be made visible by autoscrolling (x1,y1)-(x2,y2) describes a rectangle on the screen which you would like autoscrolled into view.

element.name: SPOS_FORCEDRAG
element.short: Flag for ScreenPosition(). Move non-draggable screen, You may additionally set SPOS_FORCEDRAG along with any of the above. Set this if you wish to reposition an [, False] screen that you opened.

element.name: PScreenBuffer
element.short: Pointer to screen buffer

element.name: TScreenBuffer
element.short: Screen buffer structure
element.descr: Intuition supports double-buffering in screens, with friendly interaction with menus and certain gadgets. For each buffer, you need to get one of these structures from the AllocScreenBuffer() call. Never allocate your own ScreenBuffer structures! The sb_DBufInfo field is for your use.

element.name: TScreenBuffer.sb_BitMap

element.name: PIntuitionBase
element.short: Pointer to Intution basic structures

element.name: TIntuitionBase
element.short: Intuition basic structure

descr.p: It is sometimes necessary to examine the IntuitionBase structure. Items such as the address of the active screen and window, current mouse coordinates and more can be found there. It is never a good idea to simply read these fields, as they are prone to sudden change. The IntuitionBase structure must always be locked before looking at its fields.

It is necessary to inform Intuition that an application is about to examine IntuitionBase so that Intuition will not change any variables and IntuitionBase will remain static during the access. The call LockIBase(0) will lock the state of IntuitionBase so that it may be examined. During the time that the application has IntuitionBase locked, all Intuition input processing is frozen. Make every effort to examine IntuitionBase and release the lock as quickly as possible. When done call UnlockIBase(lock) where lock is what LockIBase(0) returned.

p.b: The values in IntuitionBase are read-only. Applications should never write values to IntuitionBase.

element.name: ROOTCLASS
element.short: Root Class identifier, This is the universal base class for all other classes.

descr.p: All Classes are descendants of the rootclass. There are three primary classes that descend directly from rootclass: , , and .
SuperClass: None

The following methods are described at the rootclass level although its up to the subclasses to actually implement them. If a class does not implement these methods, it should either return zero, indicating that this class does not support the method, or defer processing on to its superclass.

element.name: IMAGECLASS
element.short: Class identifier. This class is the base class for Boopsi Images.

descr.p: This class is the base class for Boopsi Images. These images are backwards compatible with the conventional Intuition Images. Every Boopsi image has an Intuition Image structure embedded in it so Intuition can access the Boopsi image as a conventional Image structure when necessary. Normally there are no direct instances of this class, only instances of subclasses of imageclass.

descr.p: This is a class of framing image, which can optionally fill itself. Its purpose is to frame other display elements using an embossed or recessed rectangular frame. The frame renders itself using the appropriate pens (, , etc.). This class is intelligent enough to bound or center its contents.
(IS)

descr.p: This is a class of system images and standard application images. There are 11 possible sysiclass image glyphs to choose from:
The class caches the image's bitmap to improve rendering speed.

element.name: GADGETCLASS
element.short: Class identifier. This is a base class for Intuition compatible gadget objects.

descr.p: This is a base class for Intuition compatible gadget objects. The dispatcher for this class takes care of creating an Intuition Gadget structure as part of its local instance data. All of the standard Boopsi gadget classes build on this class. Normally there are no direct instances of this class, only instances of subclasses of gadgetclass.

The behavior of a Boopsi gadget depends on how it handles the five Boopsi gadget methods: , , , , and . Intuition controls a Boopsi gadget by sending it these types of messages. The structures that these methods use for their messages begin with the method's ID followed by a pointer to a structure . The GadgetInfo structure is a read-only structure that contains information about the gadget's rendering environment. The gadget uses this to find things like its window, screen, or pen array. Although this structure does contain a pointer to a RastPort for the gadget, the gadget must not use this RastPort for rendering. The gadget can obtain a RastPort for rendering by calling the Intuition function ObtainGIRPort() using the GadgetInfo structure.
These methods are not defined directly by gadgetclass. It is up to subclasses of gadgetclass to implement them.

Like all Boopsi methods, these methods run on the context of the task that called the method. Normally, Intuition is the only entity that calls these methods, so these normally operate in the input.device's task. Because a gadget may have to process a large number of input events, poor implementations of gadget methods (especially the method) can degrade system performance.
(IS)

The remaining attributes defined by gadgetclass are used to set the fields in the Gadget structure of the Boopsi gadget. Some Boopsi gadgets do not pay attention to many of the fields in its Gadget structure, so most applications will not have to worry about the majority of these attributes. Some gadget classes assign special meanings to these attributes. See the documentation of the specific gadget classes for more details.
